Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And it is not possible to open it after that except by emptying the Heart (Qalb) from the power of Satan, which is the Passion (Hawa) and the Desires (Shahawat), and building it with the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted, which is the place of the effect of the angels. And Jabir ibn 'Abidah al-'Adawi said: I complained to al-'Ala' ibn Ziyad about what I find in my chest of the Whisperings (Waswasah). And for that reason, Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, My servants (Ibad) - you have no authority over them, except those who follow you of the deviators.' So everyone who follows the Passion (Hawa) is a servant of the Passion (Hawa), not a servant of Allah. And for that reason, Allah gave authority over him to Satan. And He the Exalted said: 'Have you seen the one who takes as his god his [own] desire?' And it is an indication that whoever makes his Passion (Hawa) his god and his worshipped one, he is a servant of the Passion (Hawa), not a servant of Allah. And for that reason, 'Amr ibn al-'As said to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: O Messenger of Allah, Satan comes between me and my prayer and my recitation. He said: That is a Satan called Khanzab; when you sense him, seek refuge in Allah from him and spit to your left three times. He said: So I did that, and Allah removed him from me.

For if there is an abundance of the Knowers (Al-Arifin), they would not be envious of each other; rather, they would be as their Lord, the Lord of the Worlds, said about them: 'And We will remove whatever is in their chests of rancor (Ghill) - brothers, on thrones facing each other.' Therefore, it is inconceivable that there would be envy in Paradise (Al-Jannah), nor that there would be envy among the people of the worldly life in Paradise, because Paradise has no constriction in it nor competition, and it is not attained except by the knowledge (Ma'rifah) of Allah, the Exalted, in which there is no competition in the worldly life also. Thus, the people of Paradise are necessarily free from envy (Al-Hasad) in the worldly life and the Hereafter altogether. Vol 2: Etiquette of Earning a Livelihood
If you say: Indeed, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'It was not revealed to me to gather wealth and be among the traders, but it was revealed to me: "So glorify with the praise of your Lord and be among those who prostrate (in worship)" (Quran 15:98), and worship your Lord until certainty comes to you.' The hadith: 'It was not revealed to me to gather wealth and be among the traders, but it was revealed to me: "So glorify with the praise of your Lord and be among those who prostrate (in worship)" (Quran 15:98).' Narrated by Ibn Mardawayh in the Tafsir from the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud with a chain containing weakness. And it was said to Salman al-Farsi: 'Advise us.' He said: 'Whoever among you is able to die as a pilgrim, or a warrior, or a builder of his Lord's mosque, let him do so, and do not die as a trader or a betrayer.' The answer is that the way to reconcile these reports is by detailing the circumstances. We say: We do not say that trade is absolutely better than everything, but trade is either sought for sufficiency, or wealth, or increase beyond sufficiency. If increase beyond sufficiency is sought from it for amassing and hoarding wealth, not to spend on good deeds and charities, then it is blameworthy because it is turning towards the worldly life (Dunya), the love of which is the head of every sin. If along with that he is oppressive and treacherous, then it is oppression and wickedness. This is what Salman meant by his saying: 'Do not die as a trader or a betrayer,' and by 'trader' he meant the seeker of increase. As for if it is sought for sufficiency for himself and his children, and he is able to provide for them through begging, then trade as abstention from begging is better. And if he does not need to beg and is given without begging, then earning is better because he is only given because he is a beggar by the tongue of his state and a proclaimer among people of his poverty, so abstention and concealment are more complete than idleness.
